command.headquarters_location: El Alamein defensive line, north-central sector

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical. Division at El Alamein with supply lines stretched over 1,800km from Tripoli. Water supply acute crisis in desert environment. Severe vehicle losses reduced mobility further. Fuel and ammunition critically short due to Mediterranean convoy losses. Division largely static and dependent on Axis supply coordination.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain, rocky desert, prepared defensive positions

equipment.note: 3 Battalions (reduced to 8 tubes per battalion from losses), 1 Battalion AA (reduced from 9 to 6 tubes)

tactical_doctrine.role: Binary infantry division assigned to static defensive sector at El Alamein. Heavily depleted from Gazala battles and Tobruk operations. Positioned in fortified defensive line with minefields and wire obstacles. Expected to hold ground against British attacks with minimal reserves or mobility.
special_capabilities: Experience in North African climate and conditions
Trained for positional warfare in prepared defenses
Familiarity with Allied tactics from Gazala battles
known_issues: Extreme under-strength (3,998 personnel vs. theoretical 10,400, only 38%)
Critical vehicle shortage (48 trucks vs. theoretical 800+, only 6%)
91st Regiment combat ineffective (862 personnel, ~33% of establishment)
Anti-tank capability inadequate (18x 47/32 guns, reduced from 22 in June)
Artillery depleted (24 tubes vs. 27 in June, further losses expected)
AA defense minimal (6 tubes vs. 9 in June)
Water supply crisis (3.8L/day vs. 5L minimum requirement)
Heat casualties mounting in summer temperatures (up to 43°C)
No organic armor, reconnaissance, or mobile reserves
Morale declining due to losses, heat, and supply shortages
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Tropical uniforms, reduced water rations below medical minimum, complete reliance on defensive positions with no offensive capability, modified tactics for static defense only

scenario_suitability: Static defense of El Alamein line
Second Battle of El Alamein opening phase (Oct 23, 1942)
special_rules: Static defense only: cannot conduct offensive operations
Supply crisis: check supply status every 2 turns
Extreme heat exhaustion: -2 to all actions in temperatures >40°C
AT gun obsolescence: 47/32 guns -3 penetration vs. medium/heavy armor
Water dependency: unit loses 10% effectiveness per turn beyond 1 hex from water source
Morale fragile: -1 to morale checks, rout on failed check

source: Nafziger Collection: 942IFBA - 1st Superga Division, North Africa, 15 June 1942 (baseline)
National Archives Microcopy No. T-821, Roll 144
TME 30-420 Handbook on Italian Military Forces, August 1943
Order of Battle of the Italian Army, US G-2, July 1943
Historical analysis of Italian divisional attrition July-September 1942

command.commander.name.reason: Generale di Divisione Gino Gialdi commanded Superga Division from May 1942 through First and Second Alamein. Previously commanded 52nd Torino Division.
command.commander.name.mitigation: Commander verified through multiple secondary sources

command.headquarters_location.reason: Superga Division assigned to X Corps sector in north-central El Alamein line, July-October 1942. Precise HQ coordinates not available but general sector confirmed.
sources_checked: Panzer Armee Afrika organizational charts August-September 1942
command.headquarters_location.mitigation: Sector assignment confirmed, precise coordinates require additional research

ncos.reason: June 1942 baseline (942IFBA) provides officers and troops but no NCO breakdown. Q3 attrition estimates applied proportionally but NCO-specific data unavailable.
sources_checked: Italian divisional strength returns July-September 1942 (not located)
ncos.estimate_method: Could estimate ~300-360 NCOs based on 7-9% of 3,998 total, but not included without source confirmation

personnel_and_equipment_attrition.reason: No specific strength return for Superga Division in Q3 1942 located. Estimates based on: (1) June 15 baseline from 942IFBA, (2) known Italian divisional attrition rates July-September 1942 (~14% personnel, ~20% vehicles, ~11% artillery), (3) historical accounts of Superga at First Alamein and Alam Halfa.
personnel_and_equipment_attrition.estimate_method: Applied 14% personnel attrition (4,648 → 3,998), 20% vehicle attrition (60 → 48 trucks), 11% artillery attrition (27 → 24 howitzers, 22 → 18 AT guns, 9 → 6 AA guns) based on theater-wide Italian losses July-September 1942

horses_total_and_allocation.reason: June baseline shows 528 horses (91st Regiment: 128, 92nd Regiment: 400). Applied 15% attrition for Q3 estimate: 91st Regiment 96 horses, 92nd Regiment 350 horses = 446 total.
horses_total_and_allocation.estimate_method: 15% attrition applied to horse allocation (typical for Italian divisions Q3 1942 due to heat, disease, and combat losses)

equipment_witw_ids.reason: WITW equipment database matching is Phase 5 work (currently paused). Italian equipment IDs not yet mapped.
equipment_witw_ids.mitigation: Complete Phase 5 equipment matching for Italian weapons/vehicles
